comments.raw_text:
1. read dbaron's blog at http://dbaron.org/log/20110419-animations
2. put lid down on mac book pro, leading to sleep state.
3. have dinner
4. open lid

Nightly goes up to 190% CPU for a while (20-30 secs).  

5. Close dbaron's otherwise awesome blog

CPU usage drops.

5. Close dbaron's otherwise awesome blog

comments.creator: davida@mozillafoundation.org
comments.author: davida@mozillafoundation.org
dbaron@dbaron.org
comments.creator: dbaron@dbaron.org
comments.text: Seems most likely to be a generic refresh driver issue, although I'm not sure why.
comments.raw_text: Seems most likely to be a generic refresh driver issue, although I'm not sure why.

comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.text: Hmm.  Is it possible that somehow we ended up with a REPEATING_PRECISE timer here instead of REPEATING_SLACK?  I can _definitely_ see a REPEATING_PRECISE timer having this behavior on platforms where mozilla::TimeStamp correlates well with elapsed wall-clock time across computer sleep....
comments.author: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.raw_text: Hmm.  Is it possible that somehow we ended up with a REPEATING_PRECISE timer here instead of REPEATING_SLACK?  I can _definitely_ see a REPEATING_PRECISE timer having this behavior on platforms where mozilla::TimeStamp correlates well with elapsed wall-clock time across computer sleep....

comments.text: Does it still reproduce with nightly?
comments.raw_text: Does it still reproduce with nightly?
comments.creator: vseerror@lehigh.edu
comments.author: vseerror@lehigh.edu

comments.raw_text:
FF 12 Release behaves normally, no CPU spike.

David A has a lot more extensions than I do.
comments.author: francis.uy@gmail.com
comments.creator: francis.uy@gmail.com
comments.text:
FF 12 Release behaves normally, no CPU spike.

David A has a lot more extensions than I do.

comments.raw_text: FYI, most of my extensions are disabled.
